content: Fun clash, but could use another test case. The final test case is the hardest, because it's for 'above', but clashers in Fastest mode often rush to submit after the first few tests pass and miss the fact that the final one failed. I got 75% because I was too eager to submit. :'P

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy but funny.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: That is a good clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it. It is solvable and fun. Quite easy for those who know how to approach it... I approve.

The current presentation is very confusing. Suggest to revise as follows:

* Add the following to Goal section (including the ```multi-line monospace syntax```):

```
    Your opponent's       |          Your
 power | attack direction | response | response direction 
-------+------------------+----------+--------------------
 usual | left/right/above |  defence | left/right/above
       |                  |          | (same as your
       |                  |          |  opponent)
-------+------------------+----------+--------------------
 hard  | left             |  dodging | right
       |------------------|          |--------------------
       | right            |          | left
       |------------------|          |--------------------
       | above            |          | any
```

Output
* Remove everything and add the following instead:
<<Line 1>>: Your response ({{defence}}/{{dodging}}
<<Line 2>>: Your response direction ({{left}}/{{right}}/{{above}}/{{any}})

In addition, please revise the Input section as follows:
* Add "for your opponent's power ({{usual}}/{{hard}})" to the end of Line 1's description.
* Add "for your opponent's attack direction ({{left}}/{{right}}/{{above}})" to the end of Line 2's description.

Constraints
* After the above changes, you may remove everything in this section.

Thanks.
Thank you. Already done with it. And yeah, I know about a problem with puzzle intricacy, but have no idea how to make it simply. Hope those changes will help. Thanks again!
Thank you for feedback! Well, must keep the first case because the first one should be easy to understand. Maybe I should move that one to the second

Thank you. That looks better now.

Would you please also add another validator? Currently no validator requires output of "any" (only one test does).

Thanks again.
